abstract.text: Results are presented from a search for a fourth generation of quarks produced singly or in pairs in a data set corresponding to an integrated luminosity of 5 fb À1 recorded by the CMS experiment at the LHC in 2011.
A novel strategy has been developed for a combined search for quarks of the up and down type in decay channels with at least one isolated muon or electron.

Limits on the mass of the fourth-generation quarks and the relevant Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa matrix elements are derived in the context of a simple extension of the standard model with a sequential fourth generation of fermions.

The existence of mass-degenerate fourth-generation quarks with masses below 685 GeV is excluded at 95% confidence level for minimal off-diagonal mixing between the third-and the fourth-generation quarks.
With a mass difference of 25 GeV between the quark masses, the obtained limit on the masses of the fourth-generation quarks shifts by about AE20 GeV.
These results significantly reduce the allowed parameter space for a fourth generation of fermions.

body_text.text: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks
We construct a single histogram ''template'' that contains the information of the sensitive observables from all the subsamples.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: Different template distributions are made for the signal corresponding to the different values of A and the fourth-generation quark masses m q 0 .
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: The binning of the two-dimensional observable distribution in the singlelepton subsamples with two W bosons is defined using the following procedure.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: We use a binning in the dimension of m bW such that the top-quark pair background events are uniformly distributed over the bins.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: Second, the binning in the dimension of S T in each of the m bW bins is chosen to obtain uniformly distributed top-quark pair events also in this dimension.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: The templates of the sensitive observables are used as input to obtain the likelihoods for the background-only and the signal-plus-background hypotheses.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: Systematic uncertainties are taken into account by introducing nuisance parameters, which may affect the shape and the normalization of the templates.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: In a case where the systematic uncertainty alters the shape of the templates, template morphing [43,44] is used to interpolate linearly on a bin-by-bin basis between the nominal templates and systematically shifted ones.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: The normalization of the templates is affected by the uncertainty in the integrated luminosity, the lepton efficiency, and the normalization of the background processes.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: The integrated luminosity is measured with a precision of 2.2% [45] and has the same normalization effect on all the templates.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: The uncertainty in the lepton efficiency is a combination of the uncertainties in the trigger, selection, and identification efficiencies, which amounts to 3% and 5% for muon and electron, respectively.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: For the uncertainty in the normalization of the background processes, we use the uncertainties in the production cross section of the various standard-model processes.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: The most important contributions that affect the normalization of the templates are the 12% [33] (30%) uncertainty for the top-quark pair (single-top) production cross section and a 50% uncertainty for the W production cross section because of the large fraction of selected events with jets from heavy-flavor quarks.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: For the multilepton channel, we take into account the uncertainties in the background estimation obtained from the data.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: We also include the uncertainties in the production cross sections of Z (5% [34]), WW (35%), WZ (42%), ZZ (27%), t " t þ W (19%), t " t þ Z (28%), and W AE W AE (49%).
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: The uncertainties in the normalization of diboson and top-quark pair production in association with a boson are taken from a comparison of the next-to-leadingorder and the LO predictions.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: The largest systematic effects on the shape of the templates originate from the jet energy corrections [31] and the scale factors between data and simulation for the b-jet efficiency and the probability that a light quark or gluon is identified as a b jet [32].
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: These effects are estimated by varying the nominal value by AE1 standard deviation.

body_text.text: In the signal-plus-background model, an additional variable, defined as the cross section for the fourth-generation signal obtained by combining the separate search channels, is included.
body_text.section: B. Fitting for the presence of fourth-generation quarks

body_text.text: In the combined cross section variable, the relative fraction of each fourth-generation signal process is fixed according to the probed model parameters ðA; m q 0 Þ.

body_text.text: Using a Gaussian approximation for the probability density function of the test statistic, we determine the 95% CL expected and observed limits on the combined cross section variable using the CL s criterion [46][47][48].

body_text.text: C. Results and discussion
We use the CL s procedure to calculate the combined limit for the single-muon, single-electron, same-sign dilepton, and trilepton channels.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: When the value of the V 4Â4 CKM parameter A approaches unity, the standard model single-top and the t 0 b 0 processes reach their maximal values for the production cross section.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: When the value of A decreases, the cross section of these processes decreases linearly with A. At the same time, the expected cross section of the t 0 b and tb 0 processes increases with (1 À A) and is equal to zero for A ¼ 1.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: Therefore, the t 0 b and tb 0 processes are expected to enhance the sensitivity for fourth-generation quarks when the parameter A decreases.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: This is visible in the upper part of Fig. 2 where both the expected and observed limits on m q 0 are more stringent for smaller values of A. For instance, the limit on the fourth-generation quark masses increases by 70 GeV for A ¼ 0:9 compared to the value of the limit for A $ 1.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: While the t 0 b and tb 0 processes do not contribute for A $ 1, the inclusion of the t 0 b 0 process results in a more stringent limit (a difference of about 30 GeV) compared to when this process is not taken into account.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: The existence of fourth-generation quarks with degenerate masses is excluded for all parameter values below the line using the assumed model of the V 4Â4 CKM matrix.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: In particular, fourth-generation quarks with a degenerate mass below 685 GeV are excluded at the 95% CL for a parameter value of A $ 1.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: It is worth noting that no limits can be set for A exactly equal to unity (A ¼ 1), because in this special case, the fourth-generation quarks would be stable in the assumed model.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: The analysis is, however, valid for values of A extremely close to unity.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: The distance between the primary vertex and the decay vertex of the fourth-generation quarks is less than 1 mm for 1 À A > 2 Â 10 À14 , a number obtained using the LO formula for the decay width of the top quark in which the top-quark mass is replaced with a fourth-generation-quark mass of 600 GeV.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: Up to now, the masses of the fourth-generation quarks were assumed to be degenerate.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: However, if a fourth generation of chiral quarks exists, this is not necessarily the case.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: Therefore, it is interesting to study how the limit would change for nondegenerate quark masses.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: If we assume nondegenerate masses, another decay channel for the fourth-generation quarks is possible.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: Namely, the branching fraction for the decay of t 0 ðb 0 Þ into b 0 ðt 0 Þ, and an off-shell W boson becomes nonzero.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: For values of the mass splitting up to about 25 GeV, this branching fraction is small as noted in the introduction.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: We assume a mass splitting of 25 GeV and unchanged branching fractions for the t 0 and b 0 decays.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: The sensitivity of the analysis increases or decreases depending on the specific values of the masses and hence the production cross sections of the fourth-generation quarks.
body_text.section: C. Results and discussion

body_text.text: VI.
SUMMARY
Results from a search for a fourth generation of quarks have been presented.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: A simple model for a unitary CKM matrix has been defined based on a single parameter A ¼ jV tb j 2 ¼ jV t 0 b 0 j 2 .
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: Degenerate masses have been assumed for the fourth-generation quarks, hence m t 0 ¼ m b 0 .
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: The information is combined from different subsamples corresponding to different final states with at least one electron or muon.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: Observables have been constructed in each of the subsamples and used to differentiate between the standard-model background and the processes with fourth-generation quarks.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: With this strategy, the search for singly and pair-produced t 0 and b 0 quarks has been combined in a coherent way into a single analysis.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: Model-dependent limits are derived on the mass of the quarks and the V 4Â4
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: CKM matrix element A. The existence of fourth-generation quarks with masses below 685 GeV is excluded at 95% confidence level for minimal off-diagonal mixing between the third-and the fourth-generation quarks.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: A nonzero cross section for the single fourthgeneration quark production processes, corresponding to a value of the V 4Â4 CKM parameter A < 1, gives rise to a more stringent limit.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: When a mass difference of 25 GeV is assumed between t 0 and b 0 quarks, the limit on m t 0 shifts by about þ20ðÀ20Þ GeV for m t 0 ¼ m b 0 þ 25 GeV (m t 0 ¼ m b 0 À 25 GeV).
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY

body_text.text: These results significantly reduce the allowed parameter space for a fourth generation of fermions and raise the lower limits on the masses of the fourth generation quarks to the region where nonperturbative effects of the weak interactions are important.
body_text.section: VI. SUMMARY
